Conservatives are rallying in defense of Sandra Sellers, the professor who was fired for saying: "I end up having this angst every semester that a lot of my lower ones are Blacks. ... It‚Äôs some really good ones, but there are also usually some that are just plain at the bottom." https://t.co/5hSK5ctU9u https://t.co/sYj3RwgC7z

@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM Fifth, is independently realizing the system can be gamed actually an indicator of ability?
@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM Fourth, do certain groups get admitted who are less capable or less able to game the system?
@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM Yes, but less able to game the system may be correlated with having a worse education.
@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM It is probably an indicator of ability up to the ability of the test graders and up to their level of objectivity or bias.
@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM Are some graders biased? Probably but that needs to be demonstrated prior to any accusations to hold water.
@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM Yes.
@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM Third, has it been gamed by some but not by others?
@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM Yes. It has been gamed more by some.
@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM Second, has this been gamed?

@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM Yes, it has been gamed but probably disproportionately by the rich and connected. Some of it isn‚Äôt gaming though. Better educations often result in better and more coherent thought. Also connections are useful in life beyond law school.
@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM First, do the grades correlate with the ability to practice law?
@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM You are just confusing one set of hoops with another set of hoops.
@ravikanodia @JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM There are several overlapping issues. It makes sense to cover each.

@JakeWaltonSD @mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM In this context, the greater concern is that this professor's grades don't even accurately reflect how well the students jump through hoops, but rather are filtered through the professor's own predetermined bias of how well they jump through hoops

@ManWithAxe5 @davidciani @mjs_DC I've never met a lawyer who thinks the bar exam does anything to ensure the quality of lawyers. In fact, a few of them are actively working to change the exam to actually make it relevant

@eatsmorechicken @davidciani @mjs_DC Don't you think it should though? What is the point of grading on a curve? My law school performance, which was average, wasn't any indicator of the type of litigator I would become.

@serioustalk01 @davidciani @mjs_DC I agree. I‚Äôm not a fan of grading curves, but I think a bigger problem is the Socratic method coupled w sheer subjectivity of law school grading, and the disparities between grading methods used between schools

@StuartM21825168 @Scott_Mooney97 @overheard100 @mjs_DC No, we just eliminate the curve at American law schools. People are wildly misunderstanding the stakes in this

@Scott_Mooney97 @StuartM21825168 @overheard100 @mjs_DC The problem is the curve. These students are perfectly capable of practicing law but they're pretty much always going to get smoked by classmates who did 10 points better on the

@mjs_DC @LemieuxLGM The point being, that there is no intrinsic intelligence in this context. Certainly not one that can be identified on the basis of race. Success in this context means identifying a carefully-arranged set of hoops, and then having the proper hoop-jumping resources

@davidciani @mjs_DC Not all lawyers are equally talented or knowledgable.  Differential grading permits prospective employers to select the most qualified.

@mjs_DC How about we stop making everything a competition? You have either demonstrated you learned what you need to know to be a lawyer, or you haven‚Äôt. Making that assessment does not require a comparison to the performance of one‚Äôs peers.
@overheard100 @mjs_DC Right on. The students certainly bears no responsibility, neither do their parents and certainly not their peer group and idols in popular culture üôÑ

Some people have suggested that blind grading prevents a professor's personal biases from affecting law school grades. This class, however, was not graded blindly, and participation was 25 percent of each student's grade.
@mjs_DC Do you actually have any evidence that they are wrong? Like, any data on how black students perform compared to the rest of the body?

@ManWithAxe5 @mjs_DC If they don't learn enough, they shouldn't pass. My point is that students should be measured against the objective performance required to be competent lawyers, not against the performance of their peers.
